g.text: UMA communications platform - Alice to Bob (push data)
If Alice uses an email provider (gmail) that does not support
the WebFinger protocol, she must set up her mailbox to automatically
forward emails sent from challenge@foo.com to response@foo.com
• publishes its metadata on a URL https:
• is registered at Alice's IAM Server and is assigned 'query-users', 'view-users' admin roles, thus can query and view any user to get their claims
• can send email messages from address challenge@foo.com and retrieve from response@foo.com
• is registered at foo.com IAM Server and pre-registered as a universal AEMS public client at bar.com UMA Server
• is an agent that can act on behalf of any user registered at foo.com IAM Server
bar.com Admin has set up the Resource Server and registers it's resource set
'Incoming' and 'Outgoing' with the bar.com UMA Server with the associated scopes
• the email_address is specified by RqP Client
10. Send plain_message from challenge@foo.com to alice@gmail.com
11. Retrieve dkim_signed_message sent from alice@gmail.com to response@foo.com
if the payload is large, consider using PCT (see UMA specs. for details)
In addition to claims_token, pushed claims may also contain metadata such as:
• file_info (filename, file size, file digest, mime type)
3. bootstrap discovery of Claims Provider config url from email address via WebFinger;
if this doesn't work, build well-known url using domain part of email_address
8. evaluate other optional claims e.g. recipient_info, file_info
3. extract 'From:' part of dkim_signed_message e.g. Alice Henderson <alice@gmail.com>
4. extract claims_provider_configuration_url and ticket_challenge from dkim_signed_message
9. evaluate other optional claims e.g. recipient_info, file_info
[Alice has to demonstrate control of her mailbox]
[Alice has to demonstrate control of her mailbox]
[Domain part of email_address or WebFinger is used to locate Claims Provider configuration url]
[Alice has to demonstrate control of her mailbox]
